newsitem.title: INDIA: Bombay shares resume slide, local funds keep away.
newsitem.headline: Bombay shares resume slide, local funds keep away.

text.p: Bombay shares resumed a downtrend as support from local funds dried up with most large players remaining on the sidelines, traders said.
The benchmark 30-share index fell 60.36 points or 1.91 percent to a provisional close of 3100.16.
"Most of the domestic institutions were sitting quietly," said a trader at a foreign brokerage.
Last week, Bombay's benchmark stocks rose 59.25 points or 1.91 percent to 3160.52 after tumbling 153.46 points or 4.71 percent the week before.
Traders said the rebound was largely a result of purchases by local funds.

"Now that they (local institutions) have stabilised the drop they are staying pretty much on the sidelines. It is quite clear they were there not to make a bull but just stop the downtrend," said a chief dealer at a foreign brokerage.
He said prices had fallen on low volumes.
Traders said a one percentage point cut in the cash reserve ratios of banks -- expected to be announced in the central bank's monetary policy on Saturday -- would ease liquidity and boost sentiment.
But others said a sharp fall in the first half profits of top private firm Reliance Industries -- due on Friday -- was bound to dampen the mood.

"In the shorter-term, the Reliance results may be more important than any cut in CRR," one analyst said. A recent Reuter poll projected the petrochemical major's earnings would shrink 25 percent, hit by poor global prices.
Traders said the market expected a one-for-two bonus share issue from electrical equipment maker ABB on Thursday. But ABB shares fell and some traders forecast a lower bonus ratio.
